text: 12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 8/16/2016. Pours slightly hazy dark reddish brown color with a 1 finger foamy light khaki head with solid retention, that reduces to a thin spotty lace cap that lingers. Light spotty lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of huge chocolate, cocoa, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, bourbon, toasted oak, brown bread, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and clove; with light notes of molasses, raisin, cherry, fig, date, oak char, and roast/toasted earthiness. Increasing booze in the aromas as it warms, but not overwhelming. Damn nice aromas with great balance and complexity of dark/roast/bready malt, pumpkin, spices, and bourbon barrel notes; with great strength. Taste of huge chocolate, cocoa, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, bourbon, toasted oak, brown bread, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, and clove; with light notes of molasses, raisin, cherry, fig, date, oak char, and roast/toasted earthiness. Light-moderate roast/spice bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness on the finish. Lingering notes of chocolate, cocoa, caramel, brown sugar, vanilla, toffee, bourbon, toasted oak, brown bread, pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, clove, light molasses/dark fruit, oak char, and roast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, pumpkin, spices, and bourbon barrel flavors; with a great malt/bitter/spiciness balance, and zero cloying/astringent flavors after the finish. Light dryness from bitterness and bourbon/oak spiciness, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and medium-full body; with a smooth, moderately creamy/bready, sticky/tannic, and slightly slick/syrupy/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is fairly well hidden; a light-moderate warmth, with light barrel booziness lingering after the finish. Overall this is an amazing barrel aged imperial pumpkin porter! All around incredible complexity, robustness, and balance of dark/roast/bready malt, pumpkin, spices, and bourbon barrel flavors; very smooth and dangerously easy to sip on for the enormous ABV. Pretty much perfectly balanced between malt, spice, and bourbon barrel complexity. Great barrel presence without being too boozy, tannic, or drying. This was definitely more boozy than the Rumpkin overall, but nothing overwhelming. A highly enjoyable offering.

Bottle. Shared by clubgonzo. 18.8%, bottled Aug 16 2016. A clear dark auburn beer with a small, beige head. The aroma has a distinct pumpkin and spice touch, with caramel, nuts, prunes and figs, bread hints and alcohol. Less alcohol than expected though. Some wood, vanila and booze too. Chocolate blending in after a while. ItÂ’s full-bodied, warming and nicely carbonated, with a distinct bitterness in the mouth. Sweetness, caramel, nuts, wood, chocolate hints, brown sugar and bourbon in the flavor. Everlasting warming and sweet finish. A very complex beer indeed, damn tasteful too, but itÂ’s too boozy in the mouth I think. Superb, complex and delicious aroma. 170429

Bottle, shared with Yngwie. Pours a deep clear ruby-hued body with a small off-white head, looking amazing. Aroma is caramel, deep malts, vanilla, bourbon, wood, toffee and hints of almond brittle, nuts, alcohol cardamum and cinnamon. Taste is deep malts, caramel, vanilla, bourbon, alcohol, raisins and hints of cinnamon, cardamum, brown sugar, burnt toast and prunes. Full body, medium carbonation. For such a monster ABV, this is super balanced and very complex. The alcohol is there, but well integrated. A classic big brew from Avery, tasty and heavy just as I like it. Recommendable, and will probably cellar well for ages.

A 12 fl oz foiled bottle, Batch No.2, bottled on 7th November 2015. Poured into a snifter glass. It poured a clear dark brown amber colour with pretty much no khaki coloured head, but some sparse spotty lacing. Aromas of pumpkin pie, vanilla, cinnamon and a hit of boozy bourbon. Tastes sweet and spicy. Pumpkin pie, caramel, brown sugar, clove, cinnamon, nutmeg and all-spice with notes of oak and bourbon booziness. Lightly syrupy, full bodied, alcohol warming with light to moderate carbonation. Overall, wow, this was nice. A Pumpkin Ale thatÂ’s perhaps approaching a Winter Warmer. Great pumpkin pie spice flavours and good use of the barrel. Its quite boozy at 15% and you do get it in the aroma and taste yet at the same time, I like it, which is rare for me. Perhaps it just works for this particular style. If more Pumpkin Ales were like this, I would definitely go for the style. Good job by Avery on this one.

Taste is of chocolate, vanilla, pumpkin pie, coconut, and bourbon. Finish is warm with lingering spices, pumpkin, and booze. A great beer!

Tap; pours dark brown with a khaki head; sweet spicy aroma with malt, vanilla, molasses, caramel, and pumpkin pie spice; taste is sweet (but not overly so) with caramel, vanilla, molasses, and malt; finish has some light spice and alcohol warming; delicious!
Pours black with almost no head. Medium body. Initial taste is pumpkin pie, vanilla, bourbon and cinnamon. Finishes with a sweet pumpkin and bourbon flavor with a slight alcohol heat. Very good.

2016 version, bottled 8/16. The aroma is immediate bourbon/oak/vanilla with some pumpkin, roast and pie spice. Very boozy. Dark brown color with no head. Tastes like roasted pumpkin and pie crust. Spicy but less boozy and sweet than I was expecting. So-so palate, virtually no carbonation with a short lived aftertaste. I canÂ’t really say itÂ’s worth the money ($11.99 for 12 oz. bottle where I live). Rumpkin is better; if you must try a pumpkin beer from Avery I suggest that one.

Avery Pump[KY]n 2015 15%

Opening up this Pump[Ky]n I got a big whiff of banana bread, pouring it into my snifter the inky black gave off an aroma redolent of pumpkin pie spices (cinnamon, mace/cloves, allspice, nutmeg), hits of bourbon heat, pie crust and plum/pumpkin fruitiness.

Full bodied with a raspy carbonation, this beer delivers chocolate, molasses syrupy sweetness, spicing heading towards Christmas beer territory until you get that bread pumpkin pie spice hit in the finish. With a year on it (2015 vintage) I think itÂ’s mellowed quite a bit but the full body tells me itÂ’s probably good for another 3-5 years cellaring making me wish IÂ’d held on to it a year longer. Now that itÂ’s available in Japan (~2200 yen), I guess I can always grab another to cellar. A well made BA pumpkin brew.

Bottle Batch 3 August 16th 2016 Bottling. 18.8% ABV. First off the booze is very well concealed behind the spices and the bourbon notes. It is warm for sure but not nose clearing. This is a spicy on so if you are not on board with the pumpkin pie beer movement give it a miss. Best big beer rendition of the fall classic I have tried.
Bottle at Imazato. Huge spice nose, cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, bourbon, vanilla. Sweet and spicy with lots of barrel. Big flavor all around, and the spices are balanced by the barrel.

Draft to mini-snifter at HopCat in Ann Arbor. Looks good; a mostly transparent dark amberish brown with light beige head that steadily dissipates into lacing. Smells good; semi-sweet with a nice balance of pumpkin and related spices, vanilla, and oak. Tastes like it smells with a warming full-bodied mouthfeel. Slightly hot, but not considering the abv. A tasty sipper.

Aroma is mostly sweet and spicy, it smells like bourbon, vanilla, pumpkin spices, and some graininess. For the most part the taste is similar to the aroma, but thereÂ’s also some molasses, licorice, roasted malt and caramel noticeable. Just like the aroma, this is a very sweet and pumpkin spicy tasting brew. Mouthfeel/body is full, itÂ’s coating and creamy with a moderate amount of carbonation. I liked this brew, but I only recommend it if you like really sweet and pumpkin spice flavors. The sweet and spiciness almost got to be too much after a while, and itÂ’s not something I could drink every day. With that being said, IÂ’d certainly buy this again in the future.

The finish is long and hot.

Deep opaque brown, light tan head. Molasses and vanilla, strong alcohol, hay, light spice, some mustiness. Maybe some raisin. Very sweet, hint of bitterness. Light lingering espresso and chocolate. Quite smooth, velvety mouthfeel, bit of acidity. Pretty darn big and upfront alcohol. Quite good.

A behemoth of a beer packs a punch that can be felt all the way across the river in downtown Cincinnati. You canÂ’t get much bigger than this seasonal without turning into pure soy sauce. 

Aroma / Appearance - The deep black base sticks to the edges of the glass. Crawling downwards like slime it looks like oil residue. A dense mocha head only adds to the weighty appearance. Oak, bourbon, and spiced pumpkin from a can slowly move upwards. The thick texture covers the table with sweetness as if someone wiped up recently spilled coffee, pumpkin pie, and bourbon.

Flavor / Palate - Spiced nutmeg, bourbon, and pumpkin slices stick in the throat. The whipped cream transition coats the throat in black coffee and booze. Nothing about the beer, from start to finish, attempts to be subtle. IÂ’d love to try this again with a few years on it to see how it mellows out.

Deep brown pour with small beige head quickly dissapating. Aroma of pumpkin, caramel, nutmeg, allspice, vanilla and bourbon. Taste of pumpkin, toffee, nutmeg, cinnamon, caramel, slightly doughy and malty. Full bodied, full flavored pumpkin, slightly boozy finish with a hint of bourbon. I love these big beers!

Bottle. Batch #2, 2015. Label suggests 15%. Pours a very deep, clear mahogany with low light tan head. Aroma of pumpkin, sugar, raisins, light vanilla, milk chocolate. Taste is very sweet, pumpkin and vanilla, followed by a rich boozy warming finish. Quite odd, not necessarily bad, just weird.

12oz bottle amarillo tx. Pours a dark brown almost black with a creamy head with decent retention. Aromas are wood, cinnamon, whiskey, chocolate, vanilla undertones, pumpkin. Flavors are whoooooooooooo! I get whiskey, wood, alcohol (medium mostly in nose), slight faint pumkin, faint cinnamon. Its hard to pick up on the complexities as the alcohol blocks the nose where most of the flavors are noticed. Aftertaste is of a slight woody wood wood. It is highly, and I mean highly sweet. I guess with a porter at 15% its harder to keep it from being this sweet with all the concentrated wort. Its not that thick for how strong it is. Its more complex and interesting in the aromas that flavors.

Palate - full body, slick feel, average carbonation, spiced alcohol finish.
